event.doc_name: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: On Friday, June 6, 2025, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers carried out enforcement actions at multiple locations within Los Angeles County and the City of Los Angeles. According to news reports that rely on statements from the Department of Homeland Security, ICE officers were executing search warrants at various locations, including outside Ambiance Apparel, a clothing wholesaler. ICE reportedly also carried out enforcement activities that included detentions and arrests at a doughnut shop in the Fashion District of downtown Los Angeles and two Home Depot stores in the Westlake District in Los Angeles.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: ICE raids on Friday, June 6, 2025 in Los Angeles County and City of Los Angeles, including search warrants at Ambiance Apparel, a doughnut shop in the Fashion District, and two Home Depot stores; resulting in approximately 44 arrests and 70‑80 detentions.

evidence.text: The vehicle the President has sought to invoke for this unprecedented usurpation of state authority and resources is a statute, 10 U.S.C. § 12406, that has been invoked on its own only once before and for highly unusual circumstances not presented here. Invoking this statute, the President issued a Memorandum on June 7, 2025 (Trump Memo), “calling into Federal service members and units of the National Guard.” Secretary of Defense Hegseth, in turn, issued a Memorandum (DOD Order) that same day to the Adjutant General of California, ordering 2,000 California National Guard members into federal service.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: President Trump issued a memorandum on June 7, 2025 (Trump Memo) to federalize the National Guard and Secretary of Defense Hegseth issued a memorandum that same day ordering 2,000 California National Guard members into federal service.

evidence.text: On June 9, 2025, Secretary Hegseth issued another Memorandum (June 9 DOD Order) ordering an additional 2,000 California National Guard members into federal service.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Secretary of Defense Hegseth issued a second memorandum on June 9, 2025 ordering an additional 2,000 California National Guard members into federal service.

evidence.text: As a result, the National Guard has been deployed to Los Angeles. And now, on top of the National Guard, Defendants are reportedly also deploying Marines to the area.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The National Guard has been deployed to Los Angeles, and defendants are reportedly also deploying Marines to the area.

evidence.text: The President's federalization and deployment of the National Guard for reasons not authorized by law and without input from or consent of the Governor contravenes core statutory and constitutional restrictions.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The President’s federalization and deployment of the National Guard contravenes statutory and constitutional restrictions by proceeding without input from or consent of the Governor, violating 10 U.S.C. § 12406.

evidence.text: LAPD declared an unlawful assembly in the area of the protest site, at the intersection of Alameda and Temple Streets, and it issued an order for the protesters to disperse or be arrested. LASD positioned its officers around the intersection of Alondra Boulevard and Atlantic Avenue, and deployed less-lethal weapons. At approximately 4:00 p.m., LASD declared an unlawful assembly and instructed individuals to leave the area or be arrested.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Local law enforcement (LAPD and LASD) responded to protests, declared unlawful assemblies, issued orders for dispersal or arrest, and used less-lethal weapons such as tear gas to manage the crowds.

evidence.text: Over the course of the day, the Department of Defense (DOD) did not communicate directly with the Governor’s Office regarding any planned activation and deployment of California National Guard members. At no time prior to issuing the memorandum to federalize the California National Guard troops did the DOD seek approval from Governor Newsom to utilize California’s National Guard to protect federal agents and federal property, or otherwise notify or seek concurrence from the Governor or his office regarding the planned mobilization of the National Guard.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The Department of Defense did not notify the Governor or seek approval before federalizing the California National Guard, failing to provide the Governor with official notice or consent for the activation and deployment.

Defendants' Notice Regarding Plaintiffs' Ex Parte Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order
Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
Defendants' Corrected Opposition to Plaintiffs' Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

evidence.text: ICE and Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) officers responded to support FPS officers under siege and attempted to use non‑lethal force to disperse the crowd. ... prevented a breach of the facility.
evidence.source_document: Defendants' Corrected Opposition to Plaintiffs' Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: ICE and Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) officers responded to support FPS officers at a federal facility, preventing a breach.

evidence.text: protests turned extremely violent, with news reports showing demonstrators using chairs, dumpsters, and other weapons.
evidence.source_document: Defendants' Corrected Opposition to Plaintiffs' Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: The protest turned extremely violent, with demonstrators using chairs, dumpsters, and other weapons.

evidence.text: LAPD declared an ‘unlawful assembly’ and ordered protesters to disperse. Many did not and instead attacked LAPD officers.
evidence.source_document: Defendants' Corrected Opposition to Plaintiffs' Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: LAPD declared an ‘unlawful assembly’ and ordered protesters to disperse; many did not and attacked LAPD officers.

evidence.text: extensive damage to multiple federal buildings.
evidence.source_document: Defendants' Corrected Opposition to Plaintiffs' Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: The protest caused extensive damage to federal buildings.

evidence.text: President Trump called Governor Newsom at 10:23 pm PT that night, directed him to take action to stop the violence.
evidence.source_document: Defendants' Corrected Opposition to Plaintiffs' Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: President Trump called Governor Newsom at 10:23 pm PT on June 7 to discuss violence and Governor directed action to stop the violence.

evidence.text: Some attacked ERO and Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) officers, fought for seven hours, set at least one vehicle on fire, threw mortar‑style fireworks.
evidence.source_document: Defendants' Corrected Opposition to Plaintiffs' Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: Protesters blocked traffic and attacked ERO and CBP officers, fought for seven hours, set vehicles on fire, and threw mortar fireworks.

evidence.text: On June 6, 2025, a group of protesters tried to prevent Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officials from operating in Los Angeles by throwing objects at ICE vehicles.
evidence.source_document: Order

add_extracted.value: On June 6, 2025, protesters tried to prevent ICE officials from operating in Los Angeles by throwing objects at ICE vehicles.

evidence.text: Later that evening, protesters gathered at ICE’s Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) building in downtown Los Angeles.
evidence.source_document: Order

add_extracted.value: Later that evening, protesters gathered at ICE’s ERO building in downtown Los Angeles.

evidence.text: Protesters ‘pinned down’ several Federal Protective Service (FPS) officers and threw ‘concrete chunks, bottles of liquid, and other objects’ at the officers.
evidence.source_document: Order

add_extracted.value: Protesters pinned down FPS officers and threw concrete chunks, bottles of liquid, and other objects.

evidence.text: The protesters used ‘large rolling commercial dumpsters as a battering ram to breach the parking garage gate and damage federal property.’
evidence.source_document: Order

add_extracted.value: Protesters used large rolling commercial dumpsters as a battering ram to breach the parking garage gate and damage federal property.

evidence.text: The Los Angeles Police Department arrived on the scene about an hour after being called by federal officers.
evidence.source_document: Order

add_extracted.value: Los Angeles Police Department arrived about an hour after being called by federal officers.

evidence.text: The protesters eventually dispersed at law enforcement’s direction, but the federal building had been heavily vandalized.
evidence.source_document: Order

add_extracted.value: Protesters eventually dispersed at law enforcement’s direction but the federal building had been heavily vandalized.

evidence.text: The next day, on June 7, protesters continued to interfere with federal enforcement operations by a Homeland Security Investigations Office in Paramount, California, and continued to damage federal property. In a confrontation that lasted over seven hours, the protesters blocked traffic and used shopping carts to barricade the street. Some attacked ERO and Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) officers.
evidence.source_document: Order

add_extracted.value: On June 7, protesters interfered with federal enforcement operations by a Homeland Security Investigations Office in Paramount, CA, damaging federal property; confrontation lasted over seven hours; blocked traffic, used shopping carts to barricade street; attacked ERO and CBP officers.

evidence.text: On June 6, 2025, the federal government initiated immigration raids across the City of Los Angeles.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs' Application for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: On June 6, 2025, the federal government initiated immigration raids across the City of Los Angeles.

evidence.text: Protests swiftly followed, and some individuals involved in those protests were unruly and even violent.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs' Application for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: Protests swiftly followed, and some individuals involved in those protests were unruly and even violent.

evidence.text: State and local law enforcement responded.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs' Application for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: State and local law enforcement responded.

evidence.text: President ordered that members of the California National Guard be activated in response to the destructive fires in Los Angeles County in January 2025.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs' Application for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: President ordered that members of the California National Guard be activated in response to the destructive fires in Los Angeles County in January 2025.

evidence.text: ICE executed search warrants at multiple locations across Los Angeles.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs' Application for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: ICE executed search warrants at multiple locations across Los Angeles.

evidence.text: ICE officials ... did not brief his department, which made it difficult to respond to the mobs.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Plaintiffs' Application for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: ICE operations were alleged to have been conducted without notice to local officials.

evidence.text: members of the public gathered in protest at the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse.
evidence.source_document: Plaintiffs' Ex Parte Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: Members of the public gathered in protest at the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse on June 6, 2025.

evidence.text: protestors gathered at this location based on reports that ICE operations were happening.
evidence.source_document: Plaintiffs' Ex Parte Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: Protestors gathered at this location based on reports that ICE operations were happening.

evidence.text: The Los Angeles protests continued into Saturday June 7, and Sunday, June 8, 2025.
evidence.source_document: Plaintiffs' Ex Parte Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: Protesters gathered in Los Angeles on June 7‑8, 2025.

evidence.text: individuals who were detained during the ICE operations were being held there.
evidence.source_document: Plaintiffs' Ex Parte Motion for a Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: Individuals detained during ICE operations.
